job_title: Behavior Health Specialist in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Benefits are very good, could improve, but the company actually pays 50% of the cost of the plan which was a big improvement for me. Most of the organizations I've been apart of only pay lip service to the idea of teamwork, pitching in and helping if someone needs it. I'm happy to say that in Behavioral Health at JPS, it's definitely meant and even encouraged. My supervisor has even stepped in before to help me. No one is shamed for needing help, and we're even encouraged to ask for help. If you want to work with acute psychiatric patients, and get good experience, this is the best place for it. Also, I would say the pay is on the higher end for licensed clinicians working in behavioral health. Definitely above average, among mental health hospitals in the area, especially the private ones. Both my manager and supervisor are very supportive. Also, if you want a job that keeps you active, it's a good mix of walking and desk time.
cons: At the moment the caseload is a lot and I don't feel I get as much time as I would like with each individual patient. It's also a very quick-paced, quick-thinking and quick-response environment, and it can be stressful trying to complete everything. Also parking is TERRIBLE right now. On some days there are literally not enough spots for everyone to park.

job_title: Transition Coordinator in Fort Worth, TX
pros: JPS is amazing to work for as a hospital Coworkers are the most caring people you could meet
cons: As a transition coordinator, the focus is mainly on how many calls you can do in a day. You are expected to complete multiple assessments and assess the safety of each patient but you have to make a minimum of 25 calls a day. Within those 25 calls, you can have potential crisis situations or patients that need more attention than others. You are called out in front of the team via email by having your name highlighted in red if you do not meet the 25-call mark despite what you may have encountered that prevented you from meeting that expectation. Additionally, most days you will have more than 25 calls to make so which creates a very high-pressure environment that may lead to you not being as thorough as you would like with your patients due to lack of time. The team lead role is very unclear to the team which makes for a tension-filled workplace environment.

job_title: Case Management Coordinator in Fort Worth, TX
pros: The benefits aren't too bad, coverage available to the employee includes Cigna. $15.75/hr paycheck, much needed for some, but you also get paid more working at Harbor Freight, Bucee's Gas Station, In-N-Out Burger, and probably a bunch of other places. Pretty insulting when you have a high degree. The COVID Screeners at JPS also make about $15/hr, so you'd be better off applying to be one of them than doing the amount of work you have to for the extra 75 cents.
cons: Terrible pay considering the required experience and education for the job. Had some coworkers use very problematic language and bias show at the workplace that went unchecked. Was told that HR will always favor managers and nurses and it showed. They don't care for those that are passionate and want to help the world around them, they're there for a check and have lost their humanity. Very few that I interacted with that had tenure and felt the same as I did. Despite how discouraging it is, they still always did the best they could, but they also taught me to not work more than I'm being paid for. Easier said than done. Management/coworkers hate it when you work ahead because it makes others look bad - even though it means you're helping more people. Productivity is measured by how busy you look, and meeting the bare minimum requirements. Oh, and I was told day one there was no room for advancement.

job_title: REgistered Nurse ER in Fort Worth, TX
pros: It's a level one trauma center, so the experience can't be beat.  The patient population is challenging, as it's a county facility. Orientation for transition nurse was good, with class time and a lengthy orientation period.  Teamwork is excellent most of the time.  Overtime is always available.
cons: Chronic under-staffing and high patient ratios with high acuity make this a very challenging place to work.  There are overflow patients in the halls every shift, frequently without appropriate monitoring equipment available.  The self-scheduling tool used in the rest of the hospital is not implemented in ER.  Schedules are frequently released late and often you can't get time scheduled off when you need it even if you provide months of notice.  Management pushes hard for quick turnaround times that are not realistic given the patient load, and seem to be out of touch with what it's like to actually work there.

job_title: Outpatient Clinical Dietitian in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
- Affordable Health Insurance
- Decent PTO
- Didn't have to work weekends or cover inpatient 
- Good learning experience, especially for newer grads
cons:
- Health Insurance costs changed and were based on wages earned; someone who makes 50k vs 75k should not be paying the same amount for their insurance; those who made 49k or less paid significantly less  
- PTO had to be used for holidays even when the clinic was closed
- Hostile work environment (I was screamed at twice by a scheduling LEAD because she did not properly check in a patient and she let the patient sit in the waiting room for 2 HRS - this woman called my director at the time (she was a wonderful director) and accused me of not being at work; meanwhile I was in my office seeing a patient)
- Lowest paid RDs in Fort Worth 
- Not compensated for having a Master's Degree because "its not required for the job"
- No way to advance your career or move up (JPS does not offered tiered positions for RDS - e.g. RD I, RD II, RD III, etc.)
- Not valued as a vital member of the multidisciplinary team (EVERYONE - nurses, MAs, providers tried to offer incorrect nutrition advice instead of referring to the RD - in turn, this just confused the patients more!)
- Overworked; only 2 full-time RDs for the entire health network; on average, you'll cover 3 different clinics per week
- Performance reviews were based on the quantity of your work and not the quality of your work (you were seen as "unproductive" if you had no shows)
